Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

It is the policy of Civitas Resources that its employees, environment, property, and the public be protected from any harm that may occur as a result of its operations.  To achieve this, Civitas strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.   
Civitas implements its emergency response policies to comply with the overall corporate policies of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. Protection of the environment is also a high priority.  Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.
Facility Description

Civitas owns and operates Mustang Booster Station in Adams County, Colorado. This facility is in an open area surrounded by agricultural land; the business address is 28700 East 26th Avenue, Aurora CO, 80019 or Section 34, Township 3 South, Range 65 West.
The nearest major street is East Colfax Avenue intersecting at Hudson Road and Powhatan Road. The facility is parallel to highway 70. A dirt berm with irrigated vegetation surrounds the facility, making the facility un-visible to traffic. 
Covered Processes and Regulated Substances

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has published regulations and guidance for chemical accident prevention at facilities that handle hazardous chemicals, which can be found in the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule. These facilities, which handle certain hazardous chemicals, must develop a Risk Management Plan, which:
1.	Identifies the potential effects of a chemical accident;
2.	Identifies steps the facility is taking to prevent an accident; and
3.	Spells out emergency response procedures should an accident occur.

The list of regulated substances under the RMP program can be found at the following link: https://www.epa.gov/rmp/list-r

egulated-substances-under-risk-management-plan-rmp-program. When a facility is built, and the chemicals handled are above the listed threshold quantity, the company needs to implement a risk management program, develop the RMP, and submit it to the EPA. The plan must be revised and resubmitted to the EPA every five years.
The Mustang Booster Station handles the following regulated substances per RMP paragraph 68.130, Table 1:
Natural gas liquids can be broken into their main constituents,
	Methane
	Ethane
	Propane
	i-Butane
	n-Butane
	i-Pentane
	hexane (C6+)
Per the requirements of the RMP rule, this document addresses the following:
	Hazard assessment that details the potential effects of an accidental release, an accident history of the last five years, and an evaluation of worst-case and alternative accidental releases;

	A prevention program that includes safety precautions and maintenance, monitoring, and employee training measures; and

	Emergency response program that spells out emergency health care, employee training measures, and procedures for informing the public and response agencies (e.g., the fire department) should an accident occur.

	Safety management and continuous improvement

Summary of Offsite Consequences Analysis

Worst-case Scenario
The selected worst-case scenario for the Mustang Booster Station is a release of 160,673 lbs. of a flammable mixture from the Natural Gas Liquids (NGL) vessels resulting in a Vapor Cloud Explosion (VCE) and distance of 0.4 miles to 1-psi overpressure. 
Within Google Earth, there are zero (0), public receptors (occupied spaces) within the worst-case scenario for the NGL vessels. 

Mustang Booster Station RMP Level

The Mustang Booster Station is regulated by the federal Accidental Release Prevention Program (Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations [CFR]) and falls under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) rule 29 CFR 1910.119. 
The faci

lity is not eligible for Level 2 because it is an OSHA PSM regulated facility and is not subject to Level 3 as there are no public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a worst-case release. This places the Mustang Booster Station under the RMP Level 1 requirements.

Summary of Accidental Release Prevention Program

Accidental Release Prevention Program 
The facility has implemented a Program 1 level Prevention Program, as required by the RMP rules.  These prevention program provisions are specifically intended to minimize the probability and/or consequences of accidental NGL releases from the facility. The prevention measures include the dirt berm surrounding the facility, process safety information including SDS for all facility chemicals, fire and gas detection systems, mechanical integrity programs to ensure equipment reliability and safeguard assurance, a facility process hazard analysis to ensure adequate safeguards are implemented, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance auditing, and a management of change procedure. The facility prevention program is an ongoing program based on periodic training, incident investigations, audits, procedure revisions, and RMP updates as required to reflect facility changes and RMP requirements. 

Five-year Accident History 
The facility has had no RMP-reportable accidents/releases of NGL since the plant start-up in November of 2021. 

Emergency Response Program 
The Mustang Booster Station is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency response plan, which is in place to help protect employee and public safety as well as the environment. The plan includes information such as specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of regulated substances, procedures for informing the public and local agencies responsible for responding to an accidental release of regulated substances, information on emergency health care, name and phone numb

er of local agencies with which the emergency response plan is coordinated, and a list of all other Federal or state emergency plan requirements.

Safety Management and Changes 
The facility is committed to ensuring its operations are safe and in accordance with all RMP requirements. Facility management and technical personnel are responsible for RMP development, implementation, and compliance.  A company-wide Management of Change Program is in place to ensure that the appropriate changes occur as necessary to maintain and improve safety. Ongoing hazard reviews, training, audits, maintenance, and investigations will be conducted as required by company and government regulations.  Updates to the RMP will be completed as necessary in response to these activities.
